Award.AwardTitle: LTREB Renewal: Evaluating the Role of Metacommunity Dynamics in the Assembly of Vernal Pool Communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project leverages a long-term, highly replicated field experiment in native plant restoration to study how sustainable communities of species assemble and why they disassemble. Vernal pools, which are temporary wetlands that are inundated in spring and dry in summer, represent discrete, high diversity habitat patches for plants that are able to tolerate extreme physical conditions. The project examines naturally occurring and restored pools that vary in size, connectivity, and seeding treatment in order to identify the relative importance of local and regional factors affecting local species composition. Over the next five years, data collected on the abundance of all observed species, pollinator dynamics, seed set, germination rates, and pool hydrology will be integrated into mathematical models to determine factors that significantly influence plant species composition, community dynamics, and long-term stability.

To restore and manage natural communities effectively, ecologists must understand processes affecting their formation and dynamics. When restored ecosystems reach alternative states that do not match conservation priorities, active management is necessary to modify factors controlling the structure and composition of these communities. This field study will generate data critical to inform conservation and restoration efforts. These results will also mitigate endangered species losses on Department of Defense lands. Rural school students will participate in the project by designing and implementing their own research. Graduate and undergraduate students will also receive direct research experience through participation in the proposed field studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Efforts to understand the factors controlling the composition of local communities have played a central role in the development of ecology. The identity of colonists, the order of species colonization, and the frequency of colonization events for a given species may all affect subsequent community development. This project used the restoration of native vernal pool plant communities to test hypotheses regarding the relevance of colonization patterns on plant community formation.

 

California's vernal pools are important biological reservoirs for many species and are distinct in that they support a unique and highly endemic plant community. Vernal pools are ephemeral wetlands that experience flooding during winter rains and then undergo drought conditions in the summer and fall. Vernal pools were once widespread along the Pacific coast and Central Valley of California, but due to habitat destruction caused by urban expansion and agricultural development, it is estimated that only 3-10 % of pools remain and many vernal pool plants are now legally protected. This long-term study of restored vernal pool plant communities provided an ideal opportunity to evaluate the relative strength of interactions involved in community assembly.

  

Intellectual merit: This long-term study, using a large field experiment at Travis Air Force Base in California, focused on plant community assembly, exotic species invasions, seedbank dynamics, metapopulation and metacommunity processes, and vernal pool restoration ecology. This research revealed the importance of both abiotic (hydroperiod) and biotic (plant competition and facilitation) factors governing the long-term dynamics of these communities. Key results were: 1) Several aspects of historical contingence played key roles in the early formation of vernal pool plant communities, but there were also reversals in community trajectories, suggesting that in this system historical effects may be lost within a decade; 2) Both seeding treatment and pool depth garnered nearly equal support as the best predictors of invasion resistance, suggesting that biotic and abiotic factors were of similar importance in retarding invasion. Moreover, extreme climatic events facilitated exotic species invasions by both reducing abiotic constraints and weakening biotic resistance to invasion; 3) The establishment of appropriate hydrological conditions in restored vernal pools was necessary, but not sufficient, to promote successful performance of vernal pool species in restored pools.  Restored pools with hydrologic conditions similar to that of naturally occurring reference pools were more likely to support populations of vernal pool plant species, but seeding increased the abundance of these species in constructed pools; 4) Functional connectivity of restored pools, as defined by immigration of plant species from a variety of nearby sources, was strongest with naturally-occurring reference pools at the study site. Specifically, species presence in a restored pool was usually well predicted by an exponential decline in connectivity with distance to reference pools, and our fitted estimates of mean dispersal distance indicate strong dispersal limitation in this system; 5) In pollination studies, gnats (Sciaridae) appeared to be filling the functional role of pollinator for the endangered plant species in the absence of solitary bees, and plant seed set appeared not to be limited by the lack of specialized bee pollinators; 6) In seed bank studies, local position in the field along inundation gradients within a pool strongly affected soil seed bank density, while seed bank diversity varied more across pool types; and 7) Using long-term weather and vegetation data, we observed that native species tended to respond positively to early-season winter precipitation, but non-native species did not.

 

Broader impacts: 1) Some of the findings from this study were distributed via an article in Science Scope, the peer-reviewed journal for middle and high school science teachers, which described experiments manipulating leaf litter and its effects on the endangered species, Lasthenia conjugens, and described how the experiment aligns with state science standards. The 6th grade teacher with whom we collaborated is a co-author on this publication; 2) We published an opinion piece in Restoration Ecology regarding the need for rigorous assessment of the performance of restoration projects. Although many restoration projects now include monitoring and evaluation in an adaptive management approach, a failure to employ distinct performance standards can lead to inconsistent and unclear results that may hinder learning from project outcomes and complicate large-scale assessments of restoration success. Our long-term data illustrate some of the challenges in using currently available vernal pool performance standard guidelines and provide suggestions for increasing their ecological relevance and clarity; 3) We collaborated with a former CU-Boulder PhD graduate, Dr. Kika Tuff, Founder of the Impact Media Lab, to prepare a publicly-accessible, award-winning research documentary that features the long-term experiment and results of this project: https://vimeo.com/228005015.
